messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): so i'm thinking of making the parser introduce xml:base attributes as the way to handle stray <base> elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:15): anyone see anything wrong with that?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): the alternatives are to have a magical base resolution mechanism and simply ignoring stray <base> tags
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:16): ie7 ignores stray <base>s, doesn't it?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:16): (or is that in standards mode only?)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): probably both
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): as in, "yes" to both questions, probably
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:17): right. and we want to deal with quirks :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:17): (at least if the web relies on them)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): i wonder if i have some data on <base> elements
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:18): it amused me when ms decided to ignore stray <base>s... obviously they based their implementation on document conformance requirements in html4
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): about 5% of sites have 1 <base> tag, apparently
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:20): uses base
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:20): but does defining it with xml:base work? i mean if there are multiple <base>s in the same parent
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): and a few thousand have more than 3
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:21): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: i would make the xml:base be set on every element until the next <base>, i guess
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:21): ah. right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): so we're talking about a few million pages here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): with 2 or more <base> elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): i wonder how many have the same URI in both <base> elements
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:22): there might be pages that use only one but have it in the middle
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:23): <link href><base href><link href>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): oh actually this was only counting _different_ values for <base>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): so a few million pages use two different values for <base>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:26): so if you serialize to xml, do you drop the <base>s?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:27): afaict browsers don't ignore <base> in xhtml
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:28): for some reason i think magical base resolution mechanism would work better
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:30): i'm not an implementor though but i'm just observing what browsers are doing today :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): yeah, dunno
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): needs to study this more
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): my main concern with supporting <base> in XHTML is that it means URI resolution will be different in XHTML UAs than pure XML UAs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:34): but i guess i can point the topic at myself
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:35): ah. so you'd like to drop support for <base> in xhtml5 completely?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): that's what the spec says today iirc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): but people have argued against that
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:36): I like base
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:36): it makes it easy to develop entire websites and then move the whole thing
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:36): only thing you need to change is a variable somewhere
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): you like <base>, or you like the concept of having a base URI?
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:36): base URI
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:36): it says authors must not use it in xml. afaict it doesn't say uas must ignore it in xml
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): ok well that's fine, nobody's talking about removing that feature :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:37): we're just talking about the syltax
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:37): pipes down
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:37): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: ah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:37): hehe
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:38): today, browsers don't ignore <base> in xml, but since 0.00% of the web use xml it might not be much of an issue to change that :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:39): yeah, especially since 95% of pages don't use base stuff at all
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:39): so that'd make it 5% of 0.00% :-)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:39): indeed :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): I guess a physicist would call that 0.000%
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:42): but <base href> changes the #document base uri. xml:base at best changes the root element's base uri
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:42): (which makes a difference with xhr iirc)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): yeah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): here's one

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:44): I thought xforms was the lightbulb
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:45): and HTML forms is LOAD AX, 1000
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:45): but we really need more declarative syntax for that
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:46): op="load" ra="ax" rb="1000" ?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:46): we need spreadsheets to make our t-shirts
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:46): it really should be <instruction><opcode>LOAD</opcode><operand type="register">AX</operand><operand type="integer-constant">1000</operand></instruction>

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): then you can abstract opcode to be a processor-independent operation, and use psuedo-registers for your registers, and allow the author to add a declarative model of their instruction set and pipeline model
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:47): don't forget version="1.0" on the <instruction> element
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): and optimal code can be generated automatically
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:48): You could do all your register allocation using XSLT
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:48): most importantly, it can be produced by authoring tools for people who don't know about markup
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:49): They don't even need to know assembly if we abstract away the commands well enough
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:55): yes, we should have declaritive expressions for spreadsheets for people who can't author them, but we should also be sure to leave <font> out of it
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:55): 'cause <font> is what those browser-makers want
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:55): bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078: to be fair, that's two separate groups of crazy people
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (02:55): but it's all crazy if you ask me
